p: The phytochemical composition of the leaves used to obtain the essential oil of C. excavata, C. harmandiana and M. koenigii are shown in Table 1. A GC-MS chromatogram is presented in Figure 3. Various compounds were detected by gas chromatography. Notably, C. harmandiana was acknowledged as a high-performance specimen containing compounds amounting to 93.60% followed by C. excavata 89.86% and M. koenigii 88.87%. Furthermore, anethole was the most dominant compound identified in essential oil, while C. excavata was found to contain the highest yield at 86.72% followed by C. harmandiana and M. koenigii at 46.09% and 26.02%, respectively.
